extendedMetadata.name: Objective
extendedMetadata.value: LO: 3.1: What factors explain the remarkable social stability achieved in early New England?

subject: US History
metadata.bookAuthor: H. W. Brands; T. H. Breen; R. Hal Williams; Ariela J. Gros
metadata.title: PRE 03 06

config.question: What did early New Englanders believe about families?

choices.content: Families were essential to maintaining social order.
The leader of the family must be a woman.
A woman need not defer to her spouse.
Men should not marry before the age of thirty.

answer_3.response: Early New Englanders believed God ordained the family for human benefit. It was essential to the maintenance of social order, since outside the family, men and women succumbed to carnal temptation.

answer_2.response: Early New Englanders believed God ordained the family for human benefit. It was essential to the maintenance of social order, since outside the family, men and women succumbed to carnal temptation.

answer_1.response: Early New Englanders believed God ordained the family for human benefit. It was essential to the maintenance of social order, since outside the family, men and women succumbed to carnal temptation.
